name: Ruy Lopez (Spanish Opening)
description: One of the oldest and most classic chess openings. The Ruy Lopez aims to pressure Black's e5 pawn while developing pieces toward castling.
main_line: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7

name: Berlin Defense (Ruy Lopez)
pgn_moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6
description: A solid defensive system against the Ruy Lopez. Popularized by Vladimir Kramnik and known for its solid but somewhat drawish reputation.
main_line: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8

name: Sicilian Defense
description: The most popular response to White's e4. Black immediately fights for the center in an asymmetrical way, leading to complex positions.

name: Najdorf Sicilian
pgn_moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6
description: One of the most respected and feared variations of the Sicilian Defense. Named after grandmaster Miguel Najdorf, it offers Black excellent counterattacking prospects.
main_line: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4

name: Queen's Gambit
description: A fundamental opening for d4 players. White offers a pawn to divert Black's d-pawn and gain central control.
main_line: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7

name: Queen's Gambit Accepted
description: Black accepts the gambit pawn but typically can't hold onto it. This leads to open positions with active piece play.
main_line: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. e3 e6 4. Bxc4 Nf6 5. Nf3

name: Queen's Gambit Declined
description: Black declines the gambit and builds a solid position. This leads to positional struggles with solid pawn structures.
main_line: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7

name: Italian Game
description: A classic opening that aims for quick development and targets the f7 square. Solid and straightforward.
main_line: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. O-O Nf6 5. d3

name: Two Knights Defense
pgn_moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nf6
description: Black challenges the Italian Game with the knight development to f6, creating immediate tactical possibilities.
main_line: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. e5

name: French Defense
description: A solid choice for Black where they prepare to challenge White's center with d5. Often leads to closed positions with distinctive pawn chains.

name: Winawer Variation (French Defense)
pgn_moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Bb4
description: A sharp variation of the French Defense where Black pins the knight and is willing to surrender the bishop pair for structural damage to White's position.
main_line: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. e5 c5 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. bxc3

name: King's Indian Defense
description: A hypermodern opening where Black allows White to build a center only to challenge it later with piece pressure and timely pawn breaks.
main_line: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 Bg7 4. e4 d6 5. Nf3 O-O

name: Scandinavian Defense
description: A direct challenge to White's e4 pawn. Black immediately counters in the center, often leading to early queen development after exchanges.
main_line: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. Nc3 Qa5

name: English Opening
description: A flexible flank opening that often transposes to other openings. White controls the d5 square and can develop in various ways.

name: King's Gambit
description: A historic and aggressive opening where White sacrifices a pawn for rapid development and attacking chances.
main_line: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5

name: Caro-Kann Defense
description: A solid option for Black that aims to counter White's center with d5. Less committal than the French Defense as the light-squared bishop can develop outside the pawn chain.
main_line: 1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4
